column21: Little Mell Fell stands as a modest but distinctive peak on the northeastern edge of the Far Eastern Fells
column22: its grassy summit offering excellent views across the surrounding terrain. The fell's name likely derives from the Old Norse "melr" meaning "sandbank
column23:
reflecting its smooth, rounded shape. Most walkers approach from the nearby village of Watermillock via the well-defined path that ascends through the fields and woodland of the lower slopes. The summit is marked by a trig point and offers superb views across the Far Eastern Fells, with particularly impressive perspectives of Ullswater and the Pennines. The northern slopes descend gently toward the shores of Ullswater, while the southern aspect drops more steeply into the valley of Aira Beck. The predominantly grassy terrain supports hardy upland sheep grazing, with few rocky features to break the smooth contours that characterize much of this section of the Far Eastern Fells. Despite its modest height, Little Mell Fell's strategic position above Ullswater and its easily accessible nature make it a popular objective for those seeking impressive views without a full mountain ascent.
2445,Great Mell Fell,Lake District - Far Eastern Fells,EL06,Westmorland and Furness,Hu
column44: Great Mell Fell forms a broad
column45: grassy dome on the northeastern edge of the Far Eastern Fells
column46: its summit marked by a trig point. The fell's name likely derives from the Old Norse "melr" meaning "sandbank
column47:
reflecting its smooth, rounded shape. Most walkers approach from the nearby village of Matterdale End via the well-defined path that ascends through the fields and woodland of the lower slopes. The summit offers excellent panoramic views across the Far Eastern Fells, with particularly impressive perspectives of Blencathra and the Pennines. The northern slopes descend gently toward the valley of the River Glenderamackin, while the southern aspect drops more steeply into the valley of Aira Beck. The predominantly grassy terrain supports hardy upland sheep grazing, with few rocky features to break the smooth contours that characterize much of this section of the Far Eastern Fells. Despite its modest height, Great Mell Fell's strategic position and the excellent views from its summit ensure its popularity with walkers exploring the Far Eastern Fells.

Most walkers approach from the nearby village of Dockray via the path that ascends through the fields and woodland of the lower slopes, or from Aira Force via the path that follows the ridge from Green Hill.
